Background:
Generate a conversation between two people (personas specified below) involving code-switching between English and Hindi. Read both personas below and generate a scenario based on both speakers.


    Personas: 
    Person1: Arjun Mehta is a 29-year-old male software engineer at Microsoft on the Azure Storage team, and he speaks English and Hindi.
    Person2: Maya Rao is a 20-year-old female student at Northeastern University majoring in Computer Science and Data Science, and she speaks English and Hindi.
    
Prompt:
This conversation should mimic inter-sentential code-switching. Inter-sentential code-switching is the practice of alternating between languages at sentence boundaries, where one complete sentence is spoken in one language and the next sentence is in a different language. Use the examples below as a reference for this conversation.

Inter-sentential Example Sentences:
1. The TA extended the deadline by 24 hours. <Hindi>कृपया आज ही ड्राफ्ट अपलोड कर दें।</Hindi>
2. <Hindi>मैंने डेटा क्लीन कर दिया है।</Hindi> The visualization notebook is ready for review.
3. I pushed the hotfix to the staging branch. The tests passed on CI. <Hindi>कल सुबह प्रोडक्शन पर डिप्लॉय करेंगे।</Hindi>
4. <Hindi>मीटिंग पाँच बजे शुरू होगी।</Hindi> <Hindi>सब लोग समय पर जुड़ें।</Hindi> The Zoom link is in the calendar invite.
5. I booked the conference room for two hours and shared the agenda with the team. We’ll walk through risks and dependencies first. <Hindi>अगर कुछ जोड़ना हो तो अभी बता दें।</Hindi>
6. <Hindi>कल का डेमो बहुत अच्छा गया।</Hindi> The client specifically liked the offline mode.
7. The crawler finished indexing the new sources. I’ve queued the embeddings job for tonight. <Hindi>सुबह तक डैशबोर्ड अपडेट मिल जाएगा।</Hindi>
8. <Hindi>फीडबैक डॉक्यूमेंट शेयर कर दिया है।</Hindi> Please add comments inline. We’ll consolidate everything by Friday.
9. I’ll send you the draft proposal by noon. <Hindi>आप बस रेफरेंसेज़ चेक कर लीजिए।</Hindi>
10. <Hindi>मैंने सभी टिकट्स को प्राथमिकता दे दी है।</Hindi> Let me know if you want any of them reassigned.


Specifications:
Generate 10-12 sentences per conversation. Alternate the speakers at every sentence. 25 percent of sentences need to include a code switch (1 out of 4 sentences). Generate ALL Hindi words in Devanagari characters, DO NOT generate Hindi words in romanized English. Generate each sentence in the following form: “<Speaker>: <sentence>.<line-break> ”. Look at the examples of code-switched and non-code-switched sentences below.

Example non-code-switched sentence: “Person1: Hi Rohan, thanks for joining the call, I wanted to discuss the current status of the feature delivery.”

Arjun: Hi Maya, thanks for jumping on this call, I wanted to discuss the latest changes to the Azure Blob Storage SDK.  
Maya: Sure thing, I think we should prioritize the pagination issue, <Hindi>क्योंकि यूज़र्स को large datasets के साथ trouble हो रही है</Hindi>, it’s affecting the analytics pipeline.  
Arjun: Agreed, I’ve already written a unit test for the new page size logic, and it passes locally on Windows and macOS.  
Maya: I can run the CI on Linux as well to catch any environment‑specific quirks, if you need me to schedule that today.  
Arjun: That would be great; let me share the test script, it’s in the repo under /tests/sdk.  
Maya: By the way, I tried the new function you added for metadata tagging, <Hindi>लेकिन यह exception throw कर रहा है जब key में special characters होते हैं</Hindi>, could we handle that better.  
Arjun: I’ll look into the encoding logic, maybe a quick regex fix will do, and I’ll add a flag for allowing unicode keys.  
Maya: Also, the documentation says we support up to 10 tags per blob, <Hindi>और अगर limit exceed हो जाए तो error return करना चाहिए</Hindi>, which matches the API spec.  
Arjun: I’ll update the validator to enforce that rule and include a test case for the boundary condition.  
Maya: Perfect, once those changes are merged, I can start drafting the release notes, <Hindi>और हम staging में rollout करने के लिए ready होंगे</Hindi>.  
Arjun: I’ll also sync with the product team to make sure the timeline aligns with the upcoming conference demo.  
Maya: Sounds good, let’s reconvene tomorrow at 10am to review the full integration tests and finalize the rollout.

Person1: Hey Daniel, thanks for meeting this afternoon. I wanted to walk through the Azure Storage prototype we’ve been iterating on.

Generate a conversation between two people (personas specified below) involving code-switching between English and Hindi. Read both personas below and generate a scenario based on both speakers.


    Personas: 
    Person1: Arjun Mehta is a 29-year-old male software engineer at Microsoft on the Azure Storage team, and he speaks English and Hindi.
    Person2: Sofia Martinez is a 21-year-old female student in a struggling group project at Boston University majoring in Information Systems, and she speaks English and Hindi.
    
Prompt:
This conversation should mimic inter-sentential code-switching. Inter-sentential code-switching is the practice of alternating between languages at sentence boundaries, where one complete sentence is spoken in one language and the next sentence is in a different language. Use the examples below as a reference for this conversation.

Inter-sentential Example Sentences:
1. The TA extended the deadline by 24 hours. <Hindi>कृपया आज ही ड्राफ्ट अपलोड कर दें।</Hindi>
2. <Hindi>मैंने डेटा क्लीन कर दिया है।</Hindi> The visualization notebook is ready for review.
3. I pushed the hotfix to the staging branch. The tests passed on CI. <Hindi>कल सुबह प्रोडक्शन पर डिप्लॉय करेंगे।</Hindi>
4. <Hindi>मीटिंग पाँच बजे शुरू होगी।</Hindi> <Hindi>सब लोग समय पर जुड़ें।</Hindi> The Zoom link is in the calendar invite.
5. I booked the conference room for two hours and shared the agenda with the team. We’ll walk through risks and dependencies first. <Hindi>अगर कुछ जोड़ना हो तो अभी बता दें।</Hindi>
6. <Hindi>कल का डेमो बहुत अच्छा गया।</Hindi> The client specifically liked the offline mode.
7. The crawler finished indexing the new sources. I’ve queued the embeddings job for tonight. <Hindi>सुबह तक डैशबोर्ड अपडेट मिल जाएगा।</Hindi>
8. <Hindi>फीडबैक डॉक्यूमेंट शेयर कर दिया है।</Hindi> Please add comments inline. We’ll consolidate everything by Friday.
9. I’ll send you the draft proposal by noon. <Hindi>आप बस रेफरेंसेज़ चेक कर लीजिए।</Hindi>
10. <Hindi>मैंने सभी टिकट्स को प्राथमिकता दे दी है।</Hindi> Let me know if you want any of them reassigned.


Specifications:
Generate 10-12 sentences per conversation. Alternate the speakers at every sentence. 25 percent of sentences need to include a code switch (1 out of 4 sentences). Generate ALL Hindi words in Devanagari characters, DO NOT generate Hindi words in romanized English. Generate each sentence in the following form: “<Speaker>: <sentence>.<line-break> ”. Look at the examples of code-switched and non-code-switched sentences below.

Example code-switched sentence: “Person1: Hey there, I hope everything is going well and <Hindi>आप कैसे हैं</Hindi> I heard the midterm on searching algorithms is next week."

Example non-code-switched sentence: “Person1: Hi Rohan, thanks for joining the call, I wanted to discuss the current status of the feature delivery.”

utterance:
Arjun: Hey Sofia, I heard your group is working on an inventory management system for the course project and I’m here to help.  
Sofia: We’re stuck on the API integration, specifically the authentication flow with Azure AD, <Hindi>अभी तो कोड में लॉगिन सही से नहीं हो रहा</Hindi> and it’s causing the whole app to crash.  
Arjun: Let me check the Azure AD documentation and we can test the integration with a sample application.  
Sofia: We’re using Azure Blob Storage for uploading data, but it’s throwing permission errors on our test runs.  
Arjun: We can set the container’s access level to container, <Hindi>बस अपने SAS token को सही स्कोप में सेट करो</Hindi> to grant read/write access.  
Sofia: Thanks, that should fix the upload; we also need to split our dataset into train and test sets and I would appreciate your recommendation.  
Arjun: You can use Python’s scikit-learn train_test_split function, or if you want to store the splits on Azure consider using Azure ML Pipelines.  
Sofia: Our team is also struggling with debugging a concurrency bug in the webhook handler that only shows up under load, and we’re not sure how to replicate it locally.  
Arjun: I suggest adding some logging statements in the handler, <Hindi>मजबूत लॉगिंग से ट्रैस कर सकते हैं</Hindi> and then analyzing the logs with Azure Application Insights.  
Sofia: That sounds like a solid plan; we’ll also look at the App Insights dashboard to spot patterns.  
Arjun: If you need any specific guidance on Azure Functions or CI/CD pipelines, I can walk you through a sample repo.  
Sofia: Thank you Arjun, this really helps our project stay on track; let’s schedule a quick call tomorrow to go over the fixes.

Generate a conversation between two people (personas specified below) involving code-switching between English and Hindi. Read both personas below and generate a scenario based on both speakers.


    Personas: 
    Person1: Daniel Kim is a 47-year-old male algorithms professor at a research university, and he speaks English and Hindi.
    Person2: Sofia Martinez is a 21-year-old female student in a struggling group project at Boston University majoring in Information Systems, and she speaks English and Hindi.
    
Prompt:
This conversation should mimic intra-sentential code-switching. Intra-sentential code-switching is the mixing of two or more languages, dialects, or registers within a single sentence. This type of switching occurs in the middle of a sentence without hesitation, seamlessly blending elements from different linguistic systems. Use the examples below as a reference for this conversation.

Intra-sentential Example Sentences:
1. <Hindi>आज थोड़ी देरी हो जाएगी</Hindi>, but I’ll still join the standup.
2. <Hindi>अगर तुम्हें सही लगे</Hindi>, we can deploy the patch tonight.
3. <Hindi>थोड़ा नेटवर्क स्लो है</Hindi>, so the upload might take longer.
4. I reviewed your PR, <Hindi>बस डॉक्यूमेंटेशन अपडेट कर दो</Hindi>, and then we can merge.
5. The lecture was great, <Hindi>खासकर जब प्रोफेसर ने उदाहरण दिए</Hindi>, it all clicked.
6. Meet me outside the library, <Hindi>जहाँ हम डिबगिंग शुरू करेंगे</Hindi>, and bring your laptop.
7. Let’s finalize the dataset split by noon, <Hindi>ताकि ट्रेनिंग समय पर शुरू हो सके</Hindi>.
8. I’ll handle the client email first, <Hindi>फिर हम रिपोर्ट पर साथ में काम करेंगे</Hindi>.
9. The prototype runs fine on my machine, <Hindi>लेकिन प्रोडक्शन के लिए और टेस्ट चाहिए</Hindi>.


Specifications:
Generate 10-12 sentences per conversation. Alternate the speakers at every sentence. 25 percent of sentences need to include a code switch (1 out of 4 sentences). Generate ALL Hindi words in Devanagari characters, DO NOT generate Hindi words in romanized English. Generate each sentence in the following form: “<Speaker>: <sentence>.<line-break> ”. Look at the examples of code-switched and non-code-switched sentences below.

Example code-switched sentence: “Person1: Hey there, I hope everything is going well and <Hindi>आप कैसे हैं</Hindi> I heard the midterm on searching algorithms is next week."

Example non-code-switched sentence: “Person1: Hi Rohan, thanks for joining the call, I wanted to discuss the current status of the feature delivery.”

utterance:
Person1: Hello Sofia, I understand the group is struggling with the recommendation system; let's outline the next steps.  
Person2: Yes, the main issue is that the collaborative filtering matrix is too sparse; we tried to fill missing values with a simple mean but the results are off.  
Person1: Let’s first examine the sparsity ratio, <Hindi>देखो</Hindi> the data distribution might indicate a bias.  
Person2: We computed the sparsity and it is around 96%; it's massive.  
Person1: Exactly. At that level, we could consider using a hybrid approach, such as combining content-based and collaborative filtering.  
Person2: That sounds promising, <Hindi>ठीक है?</Hindi> how should we implement the content features?  
Person1: You can extract genre and director vectors from the metadata and combine them with the user-item matrix using weighted concatenation.  
Person2: We'll create a feature matrix and then feed it into a gradient boosting model.  
Person1: Remember to normalize the features and use a train-test split before tuning hyperparameters; the notebook should document each step.  
Person2: Got it, <Hindi>कृपया</Hindi> check the current notebook version; we want to avoid any version conflicts.  
Person1: I've reviewed the latest commit; everything looks consistent and the code compiles without errors.  
Person2: Great! With your guidance, I think we can finalize the report and demo by Friday.

9. <Hindi>अच्छा</Hindi>, I’ll update the roadmap after the meeting.
10. Push the latest notebook to Drive, <Hindi>कृपया</Hindi>.

utterance:
Priya: Hey Arjun, I wanted to check on the progress of the new ingestion pipeline for the serverless analytics project.  
Arjun: Hi Priya, we've completed the Data Batcher Lambda and are currently validating the error handling logs.  
Priya: The team has identified a minor issue with the S3 event triggers, <Hindi>कृपया इसे जल्दी ठीक करें।</Hindi> and we can move to integration testing.  
Arjun: The Azure Storage side is ready, and I've prepared the container registry configuration for the Spark jobs.  
Priya: Great, I'll share the updated architecture diagram with the compliance team for their sign-off.  
Arjun: When we scale to the new region, we need to adjust the IAM roles, <Hindi>मुझे रोल एसेट्स की समीक्षा करने दें।</Hindi> so we avoid any permission drift.  
Priya: I'll schedule a sync meeting with the DevOps squad next week to finalize the deployment scripts.  
Arjun: I can provide the pre‑deployment checklist for the storage accounts, including the encryption keys.  
Priya: After the demo, we'll gather client feedback, <Hindi>क्लाइंट की प्रतिक्रिया दर्ज करें।</Hindi> and then prioritize the backlog items.  
Arjun: The offline mode integration is on track, and I'll push the latest build to the staging environment tonight.  
Priya: I'll review the load test results tomorrow morning and send you the summary before the stand‑up.  
Arjun: Sounds good, let me know if you need any additional logs or metrics for the report.

Inter-sentential Example Sentences:
1. The TA extended the deadline by 24 hours. <Hindi>कृपया आज ही ड्राफ्ट अपलोड कर दें।</Hindi>
2. <Hindi>मैंने डेटा क्लीन कर दिया है।</Hindi> The visualization notebook is ready for review.
3. I pushed the hotfix to the staging branch. The tests passed on CI. <Hindi>कल सुबह प्रोडक्शन पर डिप्लॉय करेंगे।</Hindi>
4. <Hindi>मीटिंग पाँच बजे शुरू होगी।</Hindi> <Hindi>सब लोग समय पर जुड़ें।</Hindi> The Zoom link is in the calendar invite.
5. I booked the conference room for two hours and shared the agenda with the team. We’ll walk through risks and dependencies first. <Hindi>अगर कुछ जोड़ना हो तो अभी बता दें।</Hindi>
6. <Hindi>कल का डेमो बहुत अच्छा गया।</Hindi> The client specifically liked the offline mode.
7. The crawler finished indexing the new sources. I’ve queued the embeddings job for tonight. <Hindi>सुबह तक डैशबोर्ड अपडेट मिल जाएगा।</Hindi>
8. <Hindi>फीडबैक डॉक्यूमेंट शेयर कर दिया है।</Hindi> Please add comments inline. We’ll consolidate everything by Friday.
9. I’ll send you the draft proposal by noon. <Hindi>आप बस रेफरेंसेज़ चेक कर लीजिए।</Hindi>
10. <Hindi>मैंने सभी टिकट्स को प्राथमिकता दे दी है।</Hindi> Let me know if you want any of them reassigned.

Look at the examples of code-switched and non-code-switched sentences below.

Example code-switched sentence: “Person1: Hey there, I hope everything is going well and <Hindi>आप कैसे हैं</Hindi> I heard the midterm on searching algorithms is next week."

Example non-code-switched sentence: “Person1: Hi Rohan, thanks for joining the call, I wanted to discuss the current status of the feature delivery.”

utterance:
Priya: Hey Arjun, I wanted to confirm the timeline for the serverless analytics pipeline release on AWS.  
Arjun: The current estimate is end of next week, but we might need an extra day for final tuning of the partition logic.  
Priya: That's fine; I'll update the stakeholder sheet accordingly and mention the buffer.  
Arjun: The CI/CD build is stuck on the container image pull, <Hindi>बस पुल करने की जरूरत है</Hindi> but I think we can resolve it by clearing the local cache.  
Priya: Could you also check the Lambda function's memory allocation, as the batch processing is failing with out-of-memory errors.  
Arjun: I’ve set the memory to 3008 MB, and the timeout to 15 minutes, which should handle the larger files without crashing.  
Priya: Great, I’ll prepare a quick runbook for the on-call team in case of any regressions during deployment.  
Arjun: After the deployment, I'll monitor the CloudWatch metrics, <Hindi>और अगर एलर्ट आए तो हम तुरंत ठीक करेंगे</Hindi> so we can keep the latency within the 200 ms SLA.  
Priya: I’ll also set up a Slack notification that tags the team when any error rate exceeds 0.5%.  
Arjun: Sounds good; I’ll create a new S3 bucket prefix for the raw data to keep the ingestion logs separate.  
Priya: Once that’s done, I’ll schedule a review meeting with the QA team to validate the end-to-end test cases.  
Arjun: Let’s also add a note in the documentation about the new event‑driven triggers, <Hindi>ताकि सभी डेवलपर्स समझ सकें</Hindi> so future contributions are smoother.

**Conversation: Career Advice for a Computer Science Student**

Person1: Hi Maya, thanks for meeting with me today! I heard you're looking for advice about your upcoming internship at Amazon.

Person2: Yes Priya di, I'm really excited but also nervous about the interview process. I've been practicing coding problems on LeetCode.

Person1: That's great! <Hindi>आपने बेसिक डेटा स्ट्रक्चर की प्रैक्टिस की है</Hindi>, right? That's crucial for technical interviews.

Person1: Absolutely! Lambda is perfect for event-driven architectures, <Hindi>लेकिन कभी-कभी cold start issues आ जाते हैं</Hindi>. Make sure to optimize your function initialization.

Person2: That's really helpful to know. I'll definitely look into that optimization technique.

Person1: One more thing, Maya - <Hindi>technical communication skills बहुत जरूरी हैं</Hindi> in a corporate setting. Practice explaining complex concepts clearly.

Person1: Perfect! <Hindi>तुम्हारी preparation और confidence दोनों strong हैं</Hindi>, so I'm sure you'll do great in your interviews.

Generate a conversation between two people (personas specified below) involving code-switching between English and Hindi. Read both personas below and generate a scenario based on both speakers.


    Personas: 
    Person1: Arjun Mehta is a 29-year-old male software engineer at Microsoft on the Azure Storage team, and he speaks English and Hindi.
    Person2: Maya Rao is a 20-year-old female student at Northeastern University majoring in Computer Science and Data Science, and she speaks English and Hindi.
    
Prompt:
This conversation should mimic inter-sentential code-switching. Inter-sentential code-switching is the practice of alternating between languages at sentence boundaries, where one complete sentence is spoken in one language and the next sentence is in a different language. Use the examples below as a reference for this conversation.

Inter-sentential Example Sentences:
1. The TA extended the deadline by 24 hours. <Hindi>कृपया आज ही ड्राफ्ट अपलोड कर दें।</Hindi>
2. <Hindi>मैंने डेटा क्लीन कर दिया है।</Hindi> The visualization notebook is ready for review.
3. I pushed the hotfix to the staging branch. The tests passed on CI. <Hindi>कल सुबह प्रोडक्शन पर डिप्लॉय करेंगे।</Hindi>
4. <Hindi>मीटिंग पाँच बजे शुरू होगी।</Hindi> <Hindi>सब लोग समय पर जुड़ें।</Hindi> The Zoom link is in the calendar invite.
5. I booked the conference room for two hours and shared the agenda with the team. We’ll walk through risks and dependencies first. <Hindi>अगर कुछ जोड़ना हो तो अभी बता दें।</Hindi>
6. <Hindi>कल का डेमो बहुत अच्छा गया।</Hindi> The client specifically liked the offline mode.
7. The crawler finished indexing the new sources. I’ve queued the embeddings job for tonight. <Hindi>सुबह तक डैशबोर्ड अपडेट मिल जाएगा।</Hindi>
8. <Hindi>फीडबैक डॉक्यूमेंट शेयर कर दिया है।</Hindi> Please add comments inline. We’ll consolidate everything by Friday.
9. I’ll send you the draft proposal by noon. <Hindi>आप बस रेफरेंसेज़ चेक कर लीजिए।</Hindi>
10. <Hindi>मैंने सभी टिकट्स को प्राथमिकता दे दी है।</Hindi> Let me know if you want any of them reassigned.


Specifications:
Generate 10-12 sentences per conversation. Alternate the speakers at every sentence. 25 percent of sentences need to include a code switch (1 out of 4 sentences). Generate ALL Hindi words in Devanagari characters, DO NOT generate Hindi words in romanized English. Generate each sentence in the following form: “<Speaker>: <sentence>.<line-break> ”. Look at the examples of code-switched and non-code-switched sentences below.

Example code-switched sentence: “Person1: Hey there, I hope everything is going well and <Hindi>आप कैसे हैं</Hindi> I heard the midterm on searching algorithms is next week."

Example non-code-switched sentence: “Person1: Hi Rohan, thanks for joining the call, I wanted to discuss the current status of the feature delivery.”

utterance:
Arjun: Hey Maya, I just finished testing the Azure Blob client and everything is passing.  
Maya: Sounds great, <Hindi>अब हम इसे staging में लगा कर देख सकते हैं</Hindi>.  
Arjun: I've already added the code coverage and pushed the PR for review.  
Maya: I saw the PR, the test suite looks solid, but the dependency version might need an update.  
Arjun: Thanks, I’ll bump the dependency version before merging to avoid compatibility issues.  
Maya: Okay, I’ll approve the changes, <Hindi>और अगर कुछ और चाहिए तो बताऊंगी</Hindi>.  
Arjun: After the merge, we should update the monitoring dashboards to include the new metrics.  
Maya: I can handle the grafana updates; the latency charts should reflect the new storage API.  
Arjun: Let’s also schedule a demo for the team next week to showcase the performance improvements.  
Maya: Great idea, <Hindi>और हमारा डेमो कुछ रीयल-वर्ल्ड डेटा के साथ कर सकते हैं</Hindi>.  
Arjun: I’ll create a slide deck with the performance graphs and the client feedback we gathered.  
Maya: Sounds perfect, I’ll prepare a short script for the demo and share it with you by tomorrow.

Background:
Generate a conversation between two people (personas specified below) involving code-switching between English and Hindi. Read both personas below and generate a scenario based on both speakers.


    Personas: 
    Person1: Arjun Mehta is a 29-year-old male software engineer at Microsoft on the Azure Storage team, and he speaks English and Hindi.
    Person2: Maya Rao is a 20-year-old female student at Northeastern University majoring in Computer Science and Data Science, and she speaks English and Hindi.
    
Prompt:
This conversation should mimic intra-sentential code-switching. Intra-sentential code-switching is the mixing of two or more languages, dialects, or registers within a single sentence. This type of switching occurs in the middle of a sentence without hesitation, seamlessly blending elements from different linguistic systems. Use the examples below as a reference for this conversation.

Intra-sentential Example Sentences:
1. <Hindi>आज थोड़ी देरी हो जाएगी</Hindi>, but I’ll still join the standup.
2. <Hindi>अगर तुम्हें सही लगे</Hindi>, we can deploy the patch tonight.
3. <Hindi>थोड़ा नेटवर्क स्लो है</Hindi>, so the upload might take longer.
4. I reviewed your PR, <Hindi>बस डॉक्यूमेंटेशन अपडेट कर दो</Hindi>, and then we can merge.
5. The lecture was great, <Hindi>खासकर जब प्रोफेसर ने उदाहरण दिए</Hindi>, it all clicked.
6. Meet me outside the library, <Hindi>जहाँ हम डिबगिंग शुरू करेंगे</Hindi>, and bring your laptop.
7. Let’s finalize the dataset split by noon, <Hindi>ताकि ट्रेनिंग समय पर शुरू हो सके</Hindi>.
8. I’ll handle the client email first, <Hindi>फिर हम रिपोर्ट पर साथ में काम करेंगे</Hindi>.
9. The prototype runs fine on my machine, <Hindi>लेकिन प्रोडक्शन के लिए और टेस्ट चाहिए</Hindi>.


Specifications:
Generate 10-12 sentences per conversation. Alternate the speakers at every sentence. 25 percent of sentences need to include a code switch (1 out of 4 sentences). Generate ALL Hindi words in Devanagari characters, DO NOT generate Hindi words in romanized English. Generate each sentence in the following form: “<Speaker>: <sentence>.<line-break> ”. Look at the examples of code-switched and non-code-switched sentences below.

Example code-switched sentence: “Person1: Hey there, I hope everything is going well and <Hindi>आप कैसे हैं</Hindi> I heard the midterm on searching algorithms is next week."

Example non-code-switched sentence: “Person1: Hi Rohan, thanks for joining the call, I wanted to discuss the current status of the feature delivery.”

utterance:
Arjun: Hey Maya, welcome to the Azure Storage team call, I hope you’re ready to dive into the new ingestion pipeline.  
Maya: Thanks Arjun, I’ve reviewed the design doc and the architecture looks solid; I’m eager to help with the streaming layer.  
Arjun: <Hindi>वैसे</Hindi>, the deploy is scheduled for tonight, so let’s confirm the current status of the data transformation jobs.  
Maya: I’ve checked the logs from the previous run and the latency is within acceptable bounds; I can run a quick load test if needed.  
Arjun: Great, we can run the load test in the sandbox environment first; the sandbox already has the latest Blob Storage SDK version.  
Maya: The dataset is ready, <Hindi>ठीक है?</Hindi> let’s kick off the job and see if the partitioning logic holds under peak load.  
Arjun: I’ll pull the latest changes from the main branch and push the updated notebook to the shared repo; you’ll receive the link shortly.  
Maya: Sounds good, I’ll also sync my local branch and verify that the unit tests pass for the storage connector module.  
Arjun: Can you review the PR, <Hindi>कृपया</Hindi> so we can merge it before the next sprint.  
Maya: I’ll start the review now, I’ll add comments on the error handling and suggest a few performance tweaks.  
Arjun: Once the PR is approved, I’ll submit the deployment pipeline to Azure DevOps, and we’ll monitor the health dashboards during rollout.  
Maya: Perfect, let’s keep an eye on the telemetry; if anything spikes, we can roll back quickly.

Maya: Hi Professor Kim, I’ve been reviewing Dijkstra’s algorithm for our graph assignment, and I have a few questions about handling edge weights.  
Daniel: Good to hear from you, Maya. Dijkstra’s algorithm works well when all edge weights are non‑negative, which is a common assumption in many practical scenarios.  
Maya: Yes, and I noticed that our sample graph includes a negative edge, so Dijkstra fails to produce the correct shortest paths.  
Daniel: Exactly, that’s why Bellman‑Ford is more appropriate for graphs that may contain negative weights or negative cycles.  
Maya: I’m trying to implement Bellman‑Ford in our Python code, <Hindi>लेकिन यहाँ पर ईजी लागत नहीं मिल रही</Hindi> because the runtime seems larger than expected.  
Daniel: The Bellman‑Ford algorithm runs in O(VE) time, which can be slow for dense graphs, but it does detect negative cycles by iterating V‑1 times.  
Maya: I plan to optimize the implementation by using an adjacency list and early termination when no distance updates occur in an iteration.  
Daniel: That’s a solid improvement; early termination reduces unnecessary passes and often cuts runtime significantly in practice.  
Maya: After that, I’ll run our test cases to verify that the algorithm correctly identifies the shortest paths and any negative cycles.  
Daniel: When you report the results, remember to include a table of distances, <Hindi>इसे वैसे ही रखना चाहिए</Hindi> and a short note on the detection of negative cycles.  
Maya: Also, I think adding a visual representation of the graph with highlighted edges will make the presentation clearer for the graders.  
Daniel: For the final demo, make sure the slides show clear charts and a concise summary, <Hindi>हमें चार्ट और टेबल साफ़ दिखाने चाहिए</Hindi> so that the audience can follow the algorithm flow without confusion.

Background:
Generate a conversation between two people (personas specified below) involving code-switching between English and Hindi. Read both personas below and generate a scenario based on both speakers.


    Personas: 
    Person1: Maya Rao is a 20-year-old female student at Northeastern University majoring in Computer Science and Data Science, and she speaks English and Hindi.
    Person2: Ethan Patel is a 12-year-old male 7th-grade student at Lincoln Middle School, and he speaks English and Hindi.
    
Prompt:
This conversation should mimic intra-sentential code-switching. Intra-sentential code-switching is the mixing of two or more languages, dialects, or registers within a single sentence. This type of switching occurs in the middle of a sentence without hesitation, seamlessly blending elements from different linguistic systems. Use the examples below as a reference for this conversation.

Intra-sentential Example Sentences:
1. <Hindi>आज थोड़ी देरी हो जाएगी</Hindi>, but I’ll still join the standup.
2. <Hindi>अगर तुम्हें सही लगे</Hindi>, we can deploy the patch tonight.
3. <Hindi>थोड़ा नेटवर्क स्लो है</Hindi>, so the upload might take longer.
4. I reviewed your PR, <Hindi>बस डॉक्यूमेंटेशन अपडेट कर दो</Hindi>, and then we can merge.
5. The lecture was great, <Hindi>खासकर जब प्रोफेसर ने उदाहरण दिए</Hindi>, it all clicked.
6. Meet me outside the library, <Hindi>जहाँ हम डिबगिंग शुरू करेंगे</Hindi>, and bring your laptop.
7. Let’s finalize the dataset split by noon, <Hindi>ताकि ट्रेनिंग समय पर शुरू हो सके</Hindi>.
8. I’ll handle the client email first, <Hindi>फिर हम रिपोर्ट पर साथ में काम करेंगे</Hindi>.
9. The prototype runs fine on my machine, <Hindi>लेकिन प्रोडक्शन के लिए और टेस्ट चाहिए</Hindi>.

Person1: Hey Ethan, I just reviewed your latest code submission for the Python loops assignment.  
Person2: Thanks Maya! I was stuck on the part where I had to count the number of vowels.  
Person1: I saw your logic, <Hindi>वैसे</Hindi> it's pretty close—just double-check the count variable.  
Person2: Okay, I'll iterate over the string and update the counter for each vowel, right?  
Person1: Exactly. Also, you can use the built‑in count method to simplify the code.  
Person2: That's neat! I'll try that approach for the rest of the assignment.  
Person1: Great job! <Hindi>अच्छा</Hindi> Once you finish, we can move on to the next module about lists.  
Person2: Sounds good. I’m curious how lists differ from arrays in Python.  
Person1: In Python, lists are dynamic and can hold mixed data types, unlike fixed‑size arrays in many languages.  
Person2: Got it. <Hindi>कृपया</Hindi> could you show me a quick example of list slicing?  
Person1: Sure, here's a slice that extracts the middle elements: my_list[2:5] returns items from index 2 to 4.  
Person2: Perfect! This makes sense now. Thanks for the help, Maya.

Prompt:
This conversation should mimic tag switching. Tag switching is a type of code-switching where short phrases or words from one language are inserted into a sentence of another. Use the examples below as a reference for this conversation.

Tag Switching Example Sentences:
1. <Hindi>वैसे</Hindi>, the deploy is scheduled for tonight.
2. The dataset is ready, <Hindi>ठीक है?</Hindi> let’s kick off the job.
3. Can you review the PR, <Hindi>कृपया</Hindi>.
4. <Hindi>देखो</Hindi>, the bug only appears on iOS 18.
5. We’ll present first and share the repo link after, <Hindi>चलो</Hindi>.
6. <Hindi>सुनो</Hindi>, the lab will be open until 9 PM.
7. The report is in your inbox, <Hindi>है ना?</Hindi>
8. We can ship the hotfix today, <Hindi>ठीक?</Hindi> if QA signs off.
9. <Hindi>अच्छा</Hindi>, I’ll update the roadmap after the meeting.
10. Push the latest notebook to Drive, <Hindi>कृपया</Hindi>.
